title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-10
content: The team discussed recent health and weather disruptions, reviewed the status of VAs previously marked as at-risk, and evaluated the effectiveness of new engagement initiatives. Key feedback from VAs regarding role clarity and compensation was addressed, along with client concerns about over-reliance on AI and communication patterns. Action plans for ongoing check-ins, anonymous feedback reporting, and client follow-ups were outlined.
key_insights: Randomized, personalized check-ins improved VA engagement and responsiveness.
VAs are experiencing scope creep and role ambiguity, leading to compensation concerns.
Clients are increasingly concerned about over-reliance on AI tools and want more sense-checking and communication.
Anonymous feedback channels are more likely to surface honest concerns from VAs.
action_items: Continue randomized, engaging check-ins with VAs.
Draft and deliver an anonymous weekly feedback summary to the client (Atlas).
Monitor and report on AI usage among VAs as requested by the client.
Meet to finalize the weekly summary for Andrea.
Await client response on role alignment and compensation feedback before further action.
best_practices: Conducting welfare check-ins at random times with personalized questions to increase engagement.
Using anonymous feedback channels to elicit honest responses.
Avoiding repetitive questioning to prevent disengagement.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-12-12
content: The team discussed outlier VAs and clients ahead of the holiday season, focusing on performance concerns, part-time VAs seeking additional hours, and client requests for replacements. Strategies for improving communication, monitoring, and converting part-time VAs to full-time were considered, with attention to avoiding cannibalization of client requests.
key_insights: Part-time VAs are more likely to seek additional clients or hours, increasing churn risk if not addressed.
Direct communication channels (WhatsApp with disappearing messages) may improve responsiveness for remote VAs.
Client requests for replacements and multiple part-time VAs in one department can signal instability or unmet needs.
Pushing part-time VAs to full-time can reduce churn risk but must be balanced against cannibalizing new client requests.
action_items: Send follow-up emails to Nicole and Joyce regarding replacement proposals.
Monitor Atlas VAs with direct messages before and after shifts, switch to WhatsApp for communication.
Draft referral suggestion wording for clients with part-time VAs seeking more hours.
Pause full-time push for Triple A part-timers until new client requests are clarified.
Share WhatsApp numbers for VAs to improve communication.
Develop SOP for part-time to full-time conversion and referral process.
best_practices: Monitor VAs closely during shift using direct messaging.
Use WhatsApp with disappearing messages for secure, responsive communication.
Suggest full-time conversion for part-time VAs at milestone check-ins.
Frame additional hours as referral opportunities to clients rather than hard push.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-15
content: The team discussed their experiences during recent typhoons, including operational disruptions such as power outages and communication issues. They reviewed the resilience and contingency planning for the VA team, shared feedback about client relationships, and outlined plans for improved support and risk forecasting. The meeting also acknowledged individual contributions and recent personal challenges among team members.
key_insights: Resilience and contingency planning are critical for VA teams during natural disasters.
Open, proactive feedback with clients (e.g., Atlas) improves partnership and retention.
Filtered but honest communication helps clients accept negative feedback constructively.
Having backup systems (e.g., Starlink, radios) is essential for business continuity.
action_items: Crissy to draft a contingency support plan for the VA team (including Starlink and radio options).
Monitor VAs who went offline during outage for ongoing risk signals.
Continue open feedback and forecasting conversations with Atlas and other clients.
Include Isaac in Starlink contingency program.
best_practices: Proactively communicating risk signals to clients and preparing replacements.
Using filtered but honest feedback to maintain client trust.
Implementing backup communication systems (Starlink, radios) for continuity.
Recognizing and supporting team members during personal and operational crises.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-22
content: The team discussed recent outlier cases among VAs, including attendance issues, personal emergencies, and resignation risks. They reviewed client satisfaction, proactive communication strategies, and handover planning to mitigate churn risk. Several action items were set to maintain VA engagement and client health.
key_insights: Proactive communication with VAs and clients reduces risk and improves satisfaction.
Personal emergencies and health issues are a significant factor in VA attendance and performance.
Timely handover planning is critical to retaining client contracts during VA transitions.
Clients value being kept informed about VA status and issues.
action_items: Follow up with Jazz on Monday for medical certificate and attendance update.
Monitor Eli's situation during typhoon season and enable offline work as needed.
Provide continued reassurance and coaching to Sancha regarding job security.
Coordinate Diana's resignation timing and handover with Treetone client.
Send check-in messages to Dorothy William and William Yam.
Schedule and conduct Monday check-ins for IP Industries VAs.
best_practices: Maintain constant communication with VAs, even for minor updates.
Inform clients promptly about VA status and emergencies.
Encourage VAs to secure medical documentation for absences.
Plan handovers proactively to retain client contracts.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-10-24
content: The team discussed recent VA replacements and ongoing client concerns, focusing on high-risk VAs and clients with repeated turnover. Key updates included profiling and onboarding a new VA (Roma) for a critical client, addressing technical issues with another VA, and handling upcoming terminations. The group reviewed action plans, risk signals, and strategies for improving retention and client satisfaction.
key_insights: Reliability and attendance are prioritized for high-turnover clients over pure performance.
Technical issues are a leading indicator of potential VA churn.
Clients with a history of multiple replacements are less open to remediation and prefer immediate replacements.
Direct, transparent feedback and daily check-ins can help mitigate risk during onboarding.
action_items: Daily start and end-of-day check-ins with Roma during onboarding.
Training Jep on AI-powered email handling and SOP mirroring from Anne.
Follow up with Jericho to ensure laptop replacement and monitor technical issue resolution.
Proceed with Mona's replacement; interviews scheduled.
Catch up with Rochelle to prepare her for mentoring Roma.
best_practices: Pre-profiling VAs before pitching replacements to clients.
Daily start and end-of-day check-ins during onboarding for at-risk placements.
Mirroring best-performing VAs' SOPs to upskill others.
Clear, direct communication with both VAs and clients regarding expectations and feedback.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-11-27
content: The team discussed upcoming holiday schedules, onboarding and data protection procedures, and focused on an outlier VA case involving Dianara's resignation and extension. The group reviewed communication processes with clients, feedback loops, and check-in protocols for VAs, highlighting a potential risk with the client Jason due to delayed notification of Dianara's resignation.
key_insights: Delayed communication of VA resignation to client can create trust issues and risk client relationship.
Onboarding packets should include explicit data protection and confidentiality guidelines, signed by VAs.
Regular check-ins with VAs after onboarding are important for early detection of issues.
action_items: Publish and require signature on onboarding packet covering confidentiality and data protection.
Consider integrating confidentiality guidelines into PTO and attendance policy documents.
Prepare to address client concerns transparently if approached about resignation communication.
Louise to share feedback from recent Atlas meeting.
Shey to follow up with Wendy regarding confidentiality practices.
best_practices: Require VAs to sign onboarding packet covering confidentiality and data sharing.
Conduct informal and formal check-ins with VAs during first week to assess adjustment and address concerns.
Avoid sharing client-specific sensitive data in daily updates.

title: Outlier Discussion - 2025-10-31
content: The team discussed year-end party plans, VA engagement strategies, and improvements to offboarding and churn analysis processes. Key focus was on communication issues with VAs, implementing structured data tracking, and developing best practices for churn risk investigation. Several action items were agreed upon to enhance reporting and root cause analysis for VA offboarding.
key_insights: Non-responsiveness in daily check-ins is a strong churn risk for VAs.
Surprise client offboardings highlight need for better data tracking and root cause analysis.
Structured data collection (spreadsheets, checklists) can improve churn prediction and post-mortem analysis.
Exit interviews and multi-source data comparison are essential for understanding churn events.
action_items: Develop a standardized report/checklist for VA offboarding events.
Create agent file spreadsheets to track VA attendance, coaching sessions, and infractions.
Implement exit interviews and root cause investigations for both VA and client sides.
Organize VA data folders with onboarding and offboarding checklists.
Present supplier options for year-end party merchandise.
best_practices: Mark VAs as orange if they are non-responsive to informal check-ins.
Use multi-source data (client, VA, third-party) for churn root cause analysis.
Maintain agent files/spreadsheets for each VA to track key metrics and events.
Conduct exit interviews for both VA and client sides to compare perspectives.

title: Insight from 2025-11-10
content: Randomized, personalized check-ins improved VA engagement and responsiveness.
searchable_text: Randomized, personalized check-ins improved VA engagement and responsiveness.

title: Insight from 2025-11-10
content: VAs are experiencing scope creep and role ambiguity, leading to compensation concerns.
searchable_text: VAs are experiencing scope creep and role ambiguity, leading to compensation concerns.

title: Insight from 2025-11-10
content: Clients are increasingly concerned about over-reliance on AI tools and want more sense-checking and communication.

content: Anonymous feedback channels are more likely to surface honest concerns from VAs.

title: Insight from 2025-12-12
content: Part-time VAs are more likely to seek additional clients or hours, increasing churn risk if not addressed.
searchable_text: Part-time VAs are more likely to seek additional clients or hours, increasing churn risk if not addressed.

title: Insight from 2025-12-12
content: Direct communication channels (WhatsApp with disappearing messages) may improve responsiveness for remote VAs.
searchable_text: Direct communication channels (WhatsApp with disappearing messages) may improve responsiveness for remote VAs.

content: Delayed communication of VA resignation to client can create trust issues and risk client relationship.
searchable_text: Delayed communication of VA resignation to client can create trust issues and risk client relationship.

title: Insight from 2025-11-27
content: Onboarding packets should include explicit data protection and confidentiality guidelines, signed by VAs.
searchable_text: Onboarding packets should include explicit data protection and confidentiality guidelines, signed by VAs.

title: Insight from 2025-11-27
content: Regular check-ins with VAs after onboarding are important for early detection of issues.
searchable_text: Regular check-ins with VAs after onboarding are important for early detection of issues.

title: Insight from 2025-10-31
content: Non-responsiveness in daily check-ins is a strong churn risk for VAs.
searchable_text: Non-responsiveness in daily check-ins is a strong churn risk for VAs.

title: Insight from 2025-10-31
content: Surprise client offboardings highlight need for better data tracking and root cause analysis.
searchable_text: Surprise client offboardings highlight need for better data tracking and root cause analysis.

title: Insight from 2025-10-31
content: Structured data collection (spreadsheets, checklists) can improve churn prediction and post-mortem analysis.
searchable_text: Structured data collection (spreadsheets, checklists) can improve churn prediction and post-mortem analysis.

title: Insight from 2025-10-31
content: Exit interviews and multi-source data comparison are essential for understanding churn events.
searchable_text: Exit interviews and multi-source data comparison are essential for understanding churn events.
